abstract: <jats:p>We analyze the risks associated with Japan’s prolonged low-interest rate policies amid a global environment of rising rates. To finance its persistent deficits, the Japanese public sector depends on inexpensive domestic funding to invest in risky assets both domestically and internationally, effectively creating a sovereign wealth fund fueled by borrowed money. Ultimately, these risks fall on Japanese bondholders, depositors, and taxpayers. While the United States faces similar fiscal pressures, it is unlikely to adopt Japan’s approach.</jats:p>
title: Japan’s Debt Puzzle: Sovereign Wealth Fund from Borrowed Money

affiliation.name: Yili Chien is Economic Policy Adviser, Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, St. Louis, Missouri.
Wenxin Du is Sylvan C. Coleman Professor of Financial Management, Harvard Business School, Boston, Massachusetts.
Hanno Lustig is Mizuho Financial Group Professor of Finance, Stanford Graduate School of Business, Stanford, California.
